bestBHT.bht: Pilate, in his attempt to evade the difficult decision of either unjustly condemning Jesus or releasing him against popular demand, sent him to Herod, following the regular practice of sending criminals to the ruler or judge of the district. This move also respected the jurisdiction and prerogative of Herod, who had authority over Galilee where Jesus had spent most of his life. However, it is worth noting that Pilate was also in Jerusalem at that time, likely hoping to gain more knowledge and possibly get rid of this troublesome case.

Henry Alford: This was the regular practice...to remit a criminal to the ruler or judge of the district."
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: thus to escape the dilemma of an unjust condemnation or an unpopular
Albert Barnes: Jesus had passed the most of his life in the part of the country where [Herod] ruled, and it was, therefore, considered that he belonged to his jurisdiction.
This was the same Herod that put John the Baptist to death.
It belonged to Herod, not to Pilate, to try this cause.
Marvin Vincent: Sent [ανεπεμψεν] . Lit., sent him up [ανα] . Used of sending up to a higher court.
Compare Acts 25:21, of sending Paul to Caesar.
It also means to send back, as in ver. 11, and Philippians 1:11.
Philip Schaff: Herod’s jurisdiction. As an inhabitant of Galilee, Jesus was under the authority of Herod Antipas, who was Tetrarch of Galilee and Perea.

The word used is a legal term generally applied to the transfer of a cause from a lower to a higher tribunal. Hence it was not to get Herod’s opinion, but to relieve himself by transferring his prisoner to Herod’s judgment.
Their quarrel (Luke 23:12) had probably been caused by some question of jurisdiction.
Archibald T. Robertson: So here was a chance to respect the prerogative (εξουσια) of Herod and get rid of this troublesome case also.
John Gill: This was Herod Antipas, the son of Herod the great, and the same that beheaded John the Baptist."

And this he did partly, that he might be rid of this troublesome business; and partly that he might show to Herod what a regard he had to his jurisdiction, and power; and that he was unwilling to break in upon it, or usurp that to himself, which did not belong to him.
Herod being born a Jew, and the son of a proselyte, was come to Jerusalem, at this time, to keep the feast of the passover."
John Wesley: He sent him to Herod — As his proper judge.

bhtAttempts.bht: Pilate, in his attempt to evade the difficult decision of either unjustly condemning Jesus or releasing him against popular demand, sent him to Herod, following the regular practice of sending criminals to the ruler or judge of the district. This move also respected the jurisdiction and prerogative of Herod, who had authority over Galilee where Jesus had spent most of his life. However, it is worth noting that Pilate was also in Jerusalem at that time, likely hoping to gain more knowledge and possibly get rid of this troublesome case.

To avoid making an unjust decision or releasing Jesus against popular demand, Pilate sent him to Herod, who had jurisdiction over Galilee where Jesus had spent most of his life. This decision not only followed the regular practice of transferring a case to a higher court but also respected Herod's authority and power. Additionally, Pilate's move provided an opportunity for him to gain more knowledge about the situation and possibly relieve himself of this troublesome case.

In order to escape the dilemma of a controversial verdict or an unpopular release, Pilate sent Jesus to Herod, who had jurisdiction over Galilee, the region where Jesus had lived. This transfer of the case from a lower to a higher tribunal respected the authority and power of Herod, while providing Pilate with a chance to gather more knowledge about the situation and potentially resolve this troublesome matter.

In an attempt to navigate the challenging decision of either unjustly condemning Jesus or releasing him against public demand, Pilate sent him to Herod. This followed the customary practice of remitting a criminal to the ruler or judge of the district. By sending Jesus to Herod, Pilate showed respect for his jurisdiction and sought to escape this troublesome case. Additionally, Pilate's decision allowed him to gain more knowledge and potentially find a resolution to the situation while he was in Jerusalem at that time.

Pilate sent Jesus to Herod to navigate between an unjust condemnation or an unpopular release. This action was regular practice, remitting criminals to the ruler or judge of the district. By honoring Herod's jurisdiction, Pilate hoped to respect his power and escape from the challenging case. This opportunity in Jerusalem allowed Pilate to gain further knowledge and possibly find a resolution to the troublesome situation.
